Tel: +380 44 424 35 72; Fax: +380 44 423 21 27 In order to successively compete with supercapacitors, an ability of fast discharge is a must for lithium-ion batteries. From this point of view, stoichiometric and substituted lithium manganese spinels as cathode materials are one of the most prospective candidates, especially in their nanosized form. In this article, an overview of the most recent data regarding physico-chemical and electrochemical properties of lithium manganese spinels, especially, LiMn2O4 and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, synthesized by means of various methods is presented, with special emphasis of their use in high-rate electrochemical applications. In particular, specific capacities and rate capabilities of spinel materials are analyzed. It is suggested that reduced specific capacity is determined primarily by the aggregation of material particles, whereas good high-rate capability is governed not only by the size of crystallites but also by the perfectness of crystals. The most technologically advantageous solutions are described, existing gaps in the knowledge of spinel materials are outlined, and the ways of their filling are suggested, in a hope to be helpful in keeping lithium batteries afloat in the struggle for a worthy place among electrochemical energy systems of the 21st century. Graphical Abstract An ideal electrode material should consist of nonaggregated, nanosized, perfect single crystals. A balance between high rate propeties and capacities should be determined not only by the size of crystals but also by their perfectness and ability to aggregation. Key words lithium-ion batteries high-rate applications cathode materials spinels 1 Introduction According to the forecasts of analytics, the world market is approaching a moment when the prices for electricity produced by lead acid or nickel metal hydride batteries and their rivals, lithium-ion batteries, will become equal [1]. Such an achievement is driven by accelerating demand from the electric and hybrid automobile market arisen from depletion of fossil fuel and turning scientists and engineers to the search of new, non-traditional sources of renewable energy manufactured and stored in a safe and viable fashion. Furthermore, clean energy generated by lithium-ion batteries is of indispensable value for solving the problem of green-house gases, which is increasingly evident in climate change. The latest reports anticipate global lithium-ion battery market revenue to surge from $19.9 billion in 2012 to $60.5 billion by 2020, with batteries fabricated specifically for electric vehicles and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles accounting for 73% of the total [2]. At the same time, the cost for lithium-ion batteries is predicted to decrease by more than 30 percent, and lithium-ion will emerge as the world's leading rechargeable battery technology. Currently, apart from automotive and energy storage applications, this kind of batteries is almost exclusively used in mobile phones and laptops, home appliances, power tools, etc. Advances in this technology are extensively reviewed, to mention just a few of the most cited ones, see Refs. [3–7]. Like any other battery, the lithium-ion battery consists of a negative electrode (anode), a positive electrode (cathode) and an electrolyte. Both electrodes are able to insert/deinsert lithium ions. During electrochemical reaction, the negative electrode is oxidized, supplying electrons to the circuit and deinserting lithium ions. Passing through the electrolyte, which is the solution of a lithium salt in an organic solvent, these ions insert into the positive electrode. The charge balance is kept by the reduction of the positive electrode by electrons from the circuit. As lithium is the lightest metal, lithium-ion batteries can store more than twice the energy of other cells of the same mass and size. The main parameters of the lithium-ion batteries are their open-circuit voltage, specific capacity, gravimetric (or volumetric) energy density, and specific rate (power density). The open-circuit voltage V 0 is determined by the Nernst equation, but due to limitations caused by sometimes unknown values of standard electrode potentials in non-aqueous media and thermodynamic properties of electrode materials it is usually a measured quantity. The specific capacity (the quantity of electricity stored) is determined in mAh·g–1 (1 Ah = 3600 C) by Faraday law as (1) Q = n F / 3.6 M where n is the number of moles of lithium ions (or electrons) involved in the electrochemical process, F = 96500 C·mol–1 is the Faraday constant, and M is the molecular mass of the electrode material. The gravimetric energy density is determined in Wh·kg–1 (1 Wh·kg–1 = 3600 J·kg–1) as (2) E = V 0 Q If V 0, Q, and E are determined by thermodynamics and electricity laws, the power density P is governed by kinetics, namely, by the diffusion of lithium ions into (and within) the grains of electrode material, and is a measured quantity. It is determined in W·kg–1 and defined as the gravimetric energy density divided by the discharge time t, (3) P = E / t It is accustomed to characterize the power density in the specific current rate units C (not to be confused with coulombs mentioned in the definitions of Q and F), [C] = A·kg–1. 1 C is a number which indicates the amount of current when the specific capacity Q of a cell is discharged in one hour, and x C is the amount of current that discharges Q in 1/x h. For one and the same cell the C units are proportional to the power density if the rated voltages upon different current loads are considered the same. Plotting energy densities vs. power densities in bilogarithmic coordinates obtains the so-called Ragone plot, which demonstrates that lithium-ion batteries offer better properties than lead acid or nickel metal hydride batteries (Figure 1 ). Clearly, high power densities are of great value in automotive applications enabling one to ensure the starting acceleration of a vehicle. However, another type of devices exists, viz., supercapacitors (shown in Ref. [10]), which offer greater discharge currents than batteries and are their natural competitors. Due to this fact, significant efforts have been undertaken towards improvements of high-rate performance of electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries. It has been already noticed that the power density is significantly governed by the diffusion of lithium ions into (and within) the grains of electrode material. This circumstance has been especially stressed in Ref. [4]. Subdivision leads to great increasing in the area of contact between electrode and electrolyte and decreasing of distances passed by electrons and lithium ions upon diffusion in the electrode material. This means that obtaining electrode materials in a nanosized form may allow for attaining greater charge/discharge rates than in the case of the electrode materials of a large particle size. However, in spite of the exponential growth of the number of followers of this idea (Figure 2a ) the dependence of the power density on the particle size is convincingly justified for surprisingly few types of electrode materials, e.g., TiO2 (shown in Refs. [11,12] and references therein) and MnO2 [13]. The number of electrode materials employed in commercialized lithium-ion batteries is quite limited (Table 1 ). Since the time when Sony released the first commercial lithium-ion battery in 1991, LiCoO2 remains the most popular cathode material. It offers quite high energy density, but presents safety risks due to high toxicity of cobalt compounds. Lithium-manganese spinel LiMn2O4 as a cathode material for lithium ion batteries has been suggested in 1983 [14] and since that time attracts much attention of experimentalists [3,6]. Compared to currently employed LiCoO2, it is cheap, non-toxic and environmentally benign, and has a high potential against lithium electrode (3.0–4.5 V) and the theoretical capacity of 148 mAh·g–1. One of approaches enabling one to expand electrochemical parameters of lithium-manganese spinels is doping its structure with transition metal ions thus getting various compounds of the general formula of LiMe1–x Me x O4 [16]. The number of papers dealing with lithium-manganese spinels is continuously growing; as an example, the dynamics of citation of the first paper on electrochemical properties of LiMn2O4 is shown in Figure 2(b). Various synthetic approaches are probed, from standard solid state techniques to sol-gel routes and methods adopted in nanochemistry for the synthesis of nanostructured materials (nanowires, nanorods, nanosheets, etc.). Looking through these papers one reassures that serious gaps exist in the data accumulated to date. For example, theoretical capacities of materials studied are barely attained, and the causes of this fact remain unknown. However, even for such non-optimal materials, quite high discharge rates are sometimes registered, demonstrating good prospects of lithium-manganese spinels in heavy-duty applications. Unlike other materials, for which the dependence of the power density on the particle size has been clearly shown [11–13], there are no proofs of possible advantages of sol-gel and/or nanochemistry routes over conventional solid state techniques. As an example one may quote a paper by Scrosati and co-workers [17] attempting at a screening of possible synthetic strategies including solid state, wet chemistry, combustion synthesis, and three sol-gel routes. In all cases, except the solid state method, practical capacities are far from theoretical values. The best capacity retention over 500 cycles is demonstrated by the sample obtained by a wet chemistry route. On the other hand, the best high-rate properties are revealed by the sample obtained by the solid state route. The authors conclude that many aspects of the synthesis of materials under study following sol-gel routes need to be improved. In our recent papers, an optimized (sol-gel-like) citric acid aided procedure for obtaining powdered oxide materials of regulated porosity and specific surface area has been proposed [18–20]. Using this route we have obtained and tested several electrode materials having good high-rate properties [21–24]. Aiming at continuing these efforts, we present here an overview of the most recent data regarding physicochemical and electrochemical properties of lithium manganese spinels, especially, LiMn2O4 and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, synthesized by means of various methods, with special emphasis of their use in high-rate electrochemical applications. Clearly, we are far from being sure that all existing works on the subject are embraced in this survey; Figure 2 shows that the number of literature sources in the field is enormous, and we rather select some papers published in the last five to seven years, which, to our opinion, are the most significant for attaining the maximally high discharge rates and approaching the theoretical capacity values. 2 Structure and properties of lithium manganese spinels LiMn2O4 belongs to the face-centered cubic Fd 3 m space group, Z = 8 [25,26]. In this cubic structure (Figure 3 ), oxygen ions occupy the 32e tetrahedral positions and form the cubic dense packing. The 16d octahedral positions are inhabited by manganese ions (Mn3+/Mn4+). Lithium ions hold the 8a tetrahedral positions. Each of them is separated from four neighboring ions by voids at 16c. This means that three-dimensional channels (8a-16c-8a-16c) exist for possible insertion and transport of lithium ions. Electrochemical intercalation/deintercalation of Li+ into/from this material occurring in the potential range of 3.0–4.5 V can be expressed as (4) LiMn 2 O 4 ↔ Li 1 - x Mn 2 O 4 + x Li + + x e - (4) In the composition range of 0⩽x⩽0.5 and 0.5⩽x⩽1.0, Reaction (4) occurs in two stages, however the spinel structure of LiMn2O4 remains cubic having the lattice parameter a = 8.248 Å. These stages are well distinguished in galvanostatic curves as separated plateaus and in cyclic voltammetry curves as two sharp peaks. As mentioned above, the theoretical capacity delivered in Reaction (4) equals to 148 mAh·g–1. Much work has been done so as to understand the nature of the Li0.5Mn2O4 phase and positioning of the lithium ions in it. Careful electrochemical, X-ray and neutron diffraction studies have shown that the charge/discharge process occurs in three steps, and hence up to three phases coexist in the 0⩽x⩽1 range [28–30]. The structure of Li0.5Mn2O4 has been determined as belonging to the modulated R3m space group, Z = 6, with the O2– ions in the 6c and 18h positions, the Mn3+ ions in the 3b positions, the Mn4+ ions in the 9e positions, and the Li+ ions partially filling 6c sites. In a cubic setting, this cell has a = 8.142 Å. Its remarkable feature is an opportunity to derive superlattices corresponding to the two “missing” phases having the predicted Li0.25Mn2O4 and Li2/3Mn2O4 compositions [30]. If x exceeds 1.0, at potentials of ~3.0 V against Li/Li+, a tetragonal LiMnO2 phase with a slightly increased unit volume (a = 8.007 Å, c = 9.274 Å) appears, (5) Li + LiMn 2 O 4 ↔ 2 LiMnO 2 Furthermore, tetragonal distortions in lithium-manganese spinels are favored by the Jahn-Teller effect which facilitates lowering the symmetry of the structure if more than 50% of Mn3+ is accumulated in the product of Reaction (5) [31]. An effect of solid state synthesis conditions and annealing of LiMn2O4 on its stoichiometry and electrochemical properties is studied in detail [32,33]. It is found that annealing at temperatures not exceeding 850 °C and slow cooling ensure the minimal loss of oxygen and maximal specific capacity. However, major drawbacks of the material are inability to gain the theoretical capacity values and a significant capacity fading on cycling (up to 10% after 50 cycles). There are two major directions in improving the electrochemical properties of the lithium manganese spinel electrode materials. One of them is based on the insertion of excess lithium ions into the 16d positions, i.e. into manganese sub-lattice, and obtaining substituted spinels of a general formula Li[Li q Mn2–q ]O4 [34–36]. Upon the substitution, the fraction of Mn3+ decreases and the specific capacity diminishes (e.g., to 117 mAh/g for Li1.063Mn1.932O4 [34] and 98 mAh/g for Li1.12Mn1.88O4 [35]). However, in this case, the mean degree of oxidation of manganese exceeds 3.5 and thus prevents the Jahn-Teller effect arising and capacity fading phenomena. Another approach enabling one to expand electrochemical parameters of lithium-manganese spinels is doping its structure with transition metal ions thus getting various compounds of the general formula of LiMe2–x Me x O4 [37]. Amidst well known materials of LiMe2–x Me x O4 composition, those doped with Me = Ni, Cr, Co, Fe, Cu are of the greatest interest [38–43]. Such a circumstance lies in the fact that the materials of this class outmatch the ordinary LiMn2O4 by the value of their high-voltage potential plateau exceeding 4.5 V and sometimes attaining 4.8–4.9 V due to the one-electron transitions of dopants, i.e. Fe2+→Fe3+, Cr2+→Cr3+, Co2+→Co3+, etc. The Ni-doped derivative of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 composition seems the most prospective among them. The thing is that unlike other dopants, the oxidation potential of nickel (Ni2+→Ni4+) is lower than 4.8 V, thus decreasing the probability of electrolyte decomposition on the surface of an electrode material. LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinel can belong to one of two space groups, viz., the ordered primitive cubic P4332 and the disordered face-centered cubic Fd3m [44,45], which differ by disordering of Ni2+ ions in the crystal lattice (a = 8.172 Å). In the ordered P4332 phase, the Mn4+ and Ni2+ ions with the ratio of 3 : 1 fill the 12d and 4a octahedral positions and the Li+ ions sit in the 8c sites (a = 8.166 Å) (Figure 3, notice that in Refs. [44,45], notation for Li positions is incorrect). In the disordered one, both cations are distributed randomly. As the scattering coefficients of nickel and manganese are very close, distinguishing between these crystalline phases by means of X-ray diffraction data is problematic, and the methods of vibrational spectroscopy are helpful in solving this problem [46,47]. On the other hand, the nanosized disordered LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 was reported to demonstrate higher electronic conductivity than the ordered one [48]. Electrochemical insertion/deinsertion of Li+ into/from LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 occurring in the potential range of 3.0–4.8 V can be expressed as (6) LiNi 0.5 Mn 1.5 O 4 ↔ Li 1 - x Ni 0.5 Mn 1.5 O 4 + x Li + + x e - Similar to LiMn2O4, galvanostatic curves for LiNio.5Mn1.5O4 are represented by separated plateaus and cyclic voltammetry curves demonstrate two peaks. In this case, however, such features arise from the stepwise oxidation/reduction of nickel ions, Ni2+→Ni3+→Ni4+. The theoretical specific capacity of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 equals to 146.7 mAh·g–1. Practical specific capacities for LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 lie within 130–140 mAh·g–1 [49,50], as opposed to other doped lithium-manganese spinels, for which those are much smaller. Important factors influencing the electrochemical parameters of the doped spinels and associated with their crystal structure are the temperature and time of a heat treatment [46–48,51,52]. The LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 samples annealed at t<700 °C are ordered, and annealing at t<700 °C gives the disordered structure [48]. As to the order-disorder transition temperature, it has been found [48] at 700–730 °C. Within this temperature interval, the beginning of another valuable process associated with the loss of oxygen falls [48]. This undesirable phenomenon leading to the oxygen deficiency and the accumulation of the Mn3+ ions can be defined by means of gravimetric analysis. Moreover, at higher temperatures, secondary phases like Li y Ni1–y O or NiO can be formed [52,53], showing up a low-voltage plateau (≈4 V). If the time and the temperature of the thermal treatment rise, the concentration of the Mn3+ ions grows and the fraction of secondary phases increases. 3 Synthetic methods for obtaining lithium manganese spinels Practice poses certain well-known requirements to mixed oxide electrode materials, first of all, to their homogeneity and to uniformity of the size of particles. Due to the need in a chemical interaction between component oxides, mechanical methods are rarely applicable, and mechanical treatment (e.g., ball milling) is sometimes employed in order to activate chemical processes. Chemical methods are the most popular in obtaining lithium manganese spinels. The chemical methods can be divided into three types, in accord with three aggregate states of the matter: (i) solid state reactions, (ii) liquid state reactions, and (iii) gas state reactions. Gas phase reactions have never been used for the synthesis of electrode materials. Solid state reactions are very common in producing oxide materials and are based on the thermal treatment of solid oxides, hydroxides and metal salts (carbonates, oxalates, nitrates, sulphates, acetates, etc.) which decompose and react forming target products and evolving gaseous products. Solid state chemistry states that powder characteristics depend on the speed of the nucleation of particles and their growth; naturally, these processes in solids are much slower than in liquids. As far as liquid state reactions are concerned, these can be performed in aqueous (wet chemistry methods) and non-aqueous solvents and can be subdivided into (i) precipitation and co-precipitation, including the so-called template synthesis, (ii) evaporation, and (iii) sol-gel methods. Precipitation is the most straightforward approach to the preparation of oxides, using hydrous oxides, carbonates, oxalates and other insoluble salts as precursors, with further thermal treatment (decomposition) of precursors. Co-precipitation is often utilized in order to obtain mixed oxides or to create tunnels or layers in the mother structure by inserting guest (template) ions. Depending on future applications, templates may be removed from the tunnel or inter-layer space by means of water (or acid) treatment. Such an approach (the so-called temptation) is quite popular in nanochemistry. Precipitation (co-precipitation) can also be performed by means of complete evaporation of a solvent. Quite close to this method is the so-called freeze drying, where the solution in the form of aerosol is sprayed into a coolant agent (e.g., liquid nitrogen). Another approach based on evaporation is spray drying where a solution is sprayed into a hot chamber. In precipitation reactions, like in the case of solid state reactions, powder characteristics depend on the speed of the nucleation of particles and their growth due to the mass flow to the surfaces. In freeze drying and spray drying, powder characteristics primarily depend on the size of droplets, which in turn is determined by the parameters of a nozzle and characteristics of the flow of a carrier gas. Both these methods enable one to obtain powders with very high surface area. In sol-gel processes, an oxide network is obtained via inorganic polymerization reactions in solution. It offers many advantages if compared with conventional methods, first of all, a better control of morphology and texture of materials. Initially, it was considered that sol-gel routes are applicable to systems like silica, titania and zirconia, where hydrosols and hydrogels are formed due to the ability of hydrous oxides to set up a network where positively charged ions are linked by oxygen bridges. Later on, similar methods have been extended to almost all metal oxides: it has been found that a network could be created by hydrogen bonds formed by anions of polybasic carboxylic hydroxy and amino acids, and cations are presumably held in this network due to complex formation. An idea to use polybasic hydroxy carboxylic acids in syntheses of oxides goes back to Pechini [54]. One of the modern descriptions of the routine referred to as Pechini method reads as follows [18,20]. Citric acid forms chelates with the metal cations. When heated with a polyol, such as ethylene glycol, at a temperature of 110–150 °C these chelates undergo esterification to form a polymeric precursor resin. The cations are expected to be dispersed uniformly throughout the polymeric resin. Additional heating of the resin in air (at 400° C) results in the removal of organics and the formation of an amorphous product (sometimes called a char) with a controlled cation stoichiometry, little cation segregation, and high porosity. Sintering of the amorphous product at higher temperatures leads to the formation of oxide ceramics. Another approach somehow combining liquid-state and solid-state methods is hydrothermal (or, generally speaking, solvothermal) synthesis, where a target crystalline compound is obtained in the course of chemical reaction or by means of recrystallization performed in a two-phase (solid+liquid) system under pressure. This method is quite popular in nanochemistry, where nanostructured materials (nanowires, nanorods, etc.) are obtained from non-structured ones upon hydrothermal treatment. There are numerous advantages and shortcomings of solid state and liquid state reactions. Briefly speaking, solid state routes are often unacceptable since it is notoriously difficult to achieve proper homogeneity of materials. Liquid state routes are much more flexible and enable one to find optimal precipitating agent and/or explicitly employ principles of chemical equilibria (hydrolysis, complex formation, etc.). On the other hand, some methods of liquid state chemistry, like freeze drying and spray drying, require the use of quite expensive equipment and therefore cannot be utilized on industrial scale. During the past decades new approaches based on nanochemistry are widely implementing in electrochemical sciences. Nanochemical approaches are target-oriented, and significantly depend on the systems studied. For example, in syntheses of TiO2 and Li4Ti5O12 as anode materials, hydrothermal recrystallization leads to obtaining substances of various morphologies like nanowires, nanorods, nanotubes, etc. [55]. Templation is also useful for creating products of regulated porosity. Solid-state, liquid-state and nanochemistry methods are well presented in the papers dealing with lithium manganese spinel materials for electrochemical applications and will be discussed in what follows. 4 Properties of LiMn2O4 spinels The papers of first followers of the founders of LiMn2O4 as the cathode material contain valuable recipes regarding the regimes of the heat treatment of raw materials in solid-state procedures. For example, in Ref. [33], LiMn2O4 has been obtained from lithium carbonate and MnO2, and it has been especially emphasized that the use of other manganese oxides leads to similar results. Samples were prepared at temperatures from 600 to 1100 °C in 50 °C steps, maintained at these temperatures for 48 h, and then furnace-cooled in 3 h. For materials made below 800 °C, Li||LiMn2O4 cells with anodes prepared with the materials in question have lost capacity on the first few cycles. For materials synthesized at 800<t<1100 °C, capacity decreases with increasing synthesis temperature, and the best results have been obtained for a synthesis temperature of 800 °C. This dependence of capacity on synthesis temperature has been ascribed to differences in oxygen content between samples or to different sample morphology or grain size. Scanning electron microscopy has shown that the grain size of powders increased with increasing synthesis temperature from 1–2 μm to 10–20 μm. The theoretical capacity of LiMn2O4 is 148 mAh·g–1, but the best capacity values attained in these experiments do not exceed 120 mAh·g–1. In further electrochemical studies, the theoretical capacity of lithium manganese spinels has also been seldom reached. As follows from the data summarized in Table 2 , numerous solid-state reactions have been probed with mixtures of lithium and manganese carbonates [56,57], lithium and manganese acetates [58,59], lithium carbonate and manganese oxides (Mn3O4 [60] and MnO2 [61–63]). In addition, a combination of chemical and physical methods has been employed, where mixtures of carbonates [64], carbonates and glucose [65], and lithium carbonate and MnO2 [66] have been ball milled prior to sintering. Except some papers [65,66,59], annealing has been performed at temperatures not less than 700 °C. However, the highest capacity attained at small currents is low and does not exceed 130 mAh·g–1 [62]; in Table 2 and subsequent tables, discharge capacities at small currents which are close to theoretical values are marked bold. As follows from Table 2, solid-state methods lead to quite great spinel particles, whose size rarely becomes lower than 1 μm. High-rate data obtained by different authors significantly vary, and in order to compare them a value of the capacity loss per the unit current rate dQ d/dI is used, (7) d Q d / d I = ( Q d max - Q d min ) / ( I max - I min ) where Q d max and Q d min are discharge capacities at minimal and maximal discharge currents applied, I min and I max measured in C units. In this case, [dQ d/dI] = h means that the smaller the dQ d/dI value, the more capacity is retained upon the current load. In what follows we present dQ d/dI values for those data where the current rates of at least 10 C were employed, and dQ d/dI<2 marked bold in all tables are considered prospective for high-rate electrochemical applications. It appears that high-rate materials obtained by solid-state routes [60,64] have unacceptably low initial capacities. It has been found in the first work on the Pechini-like route for obtaining LiMn2O4 for electro-chemical application [67] that the sintering of precursors at 800 °C leads to the maximal capacity value (130 mAh·g–1) (Table 3 ). Recently, citric acid aided routes have been actively employed in the syntheses of LiMn2O4 [68,72–74]. Nanosized particles have been obtained but a high capacity value (135 mAh·g–1) has been reached just in Ref. [74]. It should be mentioned, however, that in spite of low capacities some materials obtained by a citric acid aided route demonstrate very good high-rate properties [24,73]. Pechini-like syntheses have been performed not only with citric acid, but involved other oxyacids (like tartaric [75], phthalic [76,77], adipic [78], and glycolic [79]) and glycine [80,81]. In the case of glycine, the optimal temperature of sintering has been determined as 750–800 °C, and quite high capacities (131–133 mAh·g–1) have been attained with optimal materials [80]. Even better capacities have been found for materials obtained by means of phthalic and glycolic acid aided routes (135 mAh·g–1) [76,77,79]. However, high-rate properties of these products have not been explored. It should be also mentioned that in some papers, capacities have been determined in an unacceptably broad potential range (4.7–2.5 V [76,77], 4.25–3.0 V [78]) where the Jahn-Teller effect becomes significant. In some of papers dealing with oxy- and amino-acid-aided routes [67,69,80], conclusions of Refs. [32,33] on the temperature regimes of sample annealing have been supported, and 750 °C has been considered optimal. As far as other sol-gel approaches are concerned [82–85], some of them demonstrate good prospects for obtaining spinels for electrochemical applications. Gelation with poly (vinyl pyrrolydone) leads to a product with not so high initial capacity (115 mAh·g–1) but with very good high-rate behavior [83]. A synthesis in a polymerizable resorcinol-formaldehyde matrix gives LiMn2O4 with exceptionally high initial capacity (137 mAh·g–1) and excellent high-rate properties [85]. It should be stressed that in almost all studies performed using Pechini-like and sol-gel approaches, nanosized materials have been obtained. Spray pyrolysis does not lead to spinel materials of acceptable quality [86–90] (Table 4 ). In spite of really small (nanometer) particle size, capacities appear quite low, and high-rate properties are not good. Similar conclusions regarding capacities follow for materials obtained by means of hydrothermal technique [91–94], but the high-rate properties of some of these materials appear to be excellent [93,94] (Table 4). In Ref. [89], spray pyrolysis has been used to synthesize the spinel samples enriched with carbon black. Such an approach resembles a method employed by Kang and Ceder [101], where high-rate properties of the material in question are extended by adding an extra amount of a carbonaceous material. In this case, such extension is probably caused by a supercapacitor function of the carbonaceous material and has nothing to do with the ability of the mother material to high-rate charging and discharging [102]. Other liquid-state methods, like precipitation [97], red-ox reactions [98,99], and exchange reactions (lithiation of electrolytic manganese dioxide by lithium iodide in acetonitryle) [100] sometimes lead to very good capacities (145 mAh·g–1 [98]) but yet cannot ensure acceptable high-rate properties (Table 4). Among truly nanochemical approaches applied to LiMn2O4 one should mention syntheses of hollow spheres [103–105], templation [106], self-assembling [107], nanowire growth [108], synthesis of monodispersed nanocrystals with subsequent encapsulation in mesoporous hollow silica spheres and cacination with LiOH [109], and micro-emulsion synthesis [110] (Table 5 ). In all cases, both capacities and high-rate properties appear not high. The only exception is represented by LiMn2O4 nanowires [108]. In spite of quite low initial capacity, these demonstrate excellent high-rate properties, revealing the capacity of 90 mAh·g–1 upon the load of 135C (~20 A·g–1). 5 Properties of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinels Numerous papers deal with the solid-state synthesis of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinels (Table 6 ) and various raw materials, like carbonates [111–113], acetates [17,114–117,123], nitrates [120,121], chlorides [118,119], and sulfates [124] are used. In many works, quite high values of capacity have been attained (139–150 mAh·g–1 compared to the theoretical value of 147 mAh·g–1). On the other hand, as follows from dQ d/dI values, high-rate properties of the materials obtained are poor. (As in the case of LiMn2O4, we calculate dQ d/dI just for those data where the current rates of at least 10 C were applied.) The only exception is represented by a sample synthesized using microwave heating [123]. Probably, this method might be considered useful for practical applications if more data concerning its advantages are accumulated. Optimal annealing temperatures vary from 700 to 900 °C; however, even more soft regimes appear applicable, especially in microwave experiments (500 °C [123]). In all cases except sintering after a ball-milling treatment [122], sucrose assisted combustion [120,121], and microwave treatment [124], solid state routes lead to materials with ordinary micrometer-size particles. Spray pyrolysis has been successfully used for obtaining LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinels [125–128]. Sometimes this method leads to excellent capacity and high-rate performance of the material [125], in spite of the micrometer size of the particles obtained. Sol-gel methods have been widely employed in the studies of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinels for electrochemical applications (Table 7 ). Amidst Pechini-like syntheses, the highest capacities have been attained in the cases of citric [23] and ascorbic acid aided routes [17], and exceptional heavy-duty properties have been achieved for a sample synthesized by means of a poly (ethylene glycol) assisted tartaric-acid-aided route [133]. In the latter case, however, no advantages of nanosized over microsized samples have been found. Valuable conclusions regarding the time of annealing have been made in Ref. [52], where specific capacities have been shown to decrease and rate capacity retentions increase on holding time. Similar to LiMn2O4, gelation with poly (vinyl pyrrolydone) enabled one to get a product with very good high-rate properties [137,138]. In Ref. [138], gels fired at temperatures from 800 to 1050 °C have been investigated, and capacities and high-rate behavior have been tested. It appears that annealing conditions at 850<t<1050 °C do not significantly influence either capacities (130 mAh·g–1) or high-rate performance of the samples studied, which are able to deliver 120–125 mAh·g–1 at 15 C load, the highest value attained for LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinels. Quite similar results with somewhat lower high-rate performances have been obtained by the same approach in Ref. [137]. Like in the case of LiMn2O4, a synthesis in a polymerizable resorcinol-formaldehyde matrix gives LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 with excellent high-rate properties [139], which are comparable to those for the samples obtained by means of the poly (vinyl pyrrolydone) route. Interestingly, clear advantages of disordered nickel substituted spinels over ordered ones have been proven in Ref. [139]. At small currents, capacities of disordered and ordered LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 samples are 130 and 125 mAh·g–1, respectively. Upon a 40 C load these samples deliver 100 mAh·g–1 capacities. 6 Discussion As follows from abovementioned papers, studies of Li[Li x Mn2–x ]O4 and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 in sample batteries often demonstrate extremely high capacity retention in heavy-duty tests and at the same time show shortage in capacity at small current loads. In this section, we will try to uncover the origin of such behavior from the point of view of the morphology of spinel materials. In the spirit of Aricò et al. [4], one can formulate the following requirements to electrode materials from the point of view of the accessibility of theoretical capacities and high speed of discharge of lithium batteries. An ideal electrode material should consist of nonaggregated, nanosized, perfect single crystals. The absence of aggregation would provide an access to the whole surface and whole volume of the crystals for the lithium ions migrating from the bulk of an electrolyte solution to the electrode and diffusing inside the electrode. Nanodimensionality would be the prerequisite of achieving the minimal possible times of diffusion in the solid material. The perfectness of the crystals would guarantee the absence of defect regions inaccessible to the lithium ions, i.e. would ensure the attaining of theoretical capacity. Therefore a balance between high rate properties and capacities should be determined not only by the size of crystals but also by their perfectness and ability to aggregation. These requirements can be illustrated by Figure 4 . Naturally, being perfect crystals of either micrometer (Figure 4a) or nanometer dimensions (Figure 4b), electrode materials must be able to be discharged with great currents, at the same time demonstrating specific capacities close to theoretical values. In well-shaped microsized and nanosized crystals, such imperfections as dislocations, domain boundaries, etc., should not cause significant resistance to the diffusion of the lithium ions (Figure 4d). These crystals will be able to be discharged with great currents and demonstrate high specific capacities. The same is probably applicable for regularly accreted well-shaped crystals of any size (Figure 4d). The possible presence of defect domains and non-conductive crystallites (colored regions in Figure 4e) decreases specific capacity but does not influence the speed of diffusion. In chaotically accreted, aggregated crystals, an access of the electrolyte to the inner part of aggregates will be hampered. This will greatly decrease specific capacity. However, ability to the fast discharge may be secured by external crystals and will not be reduced significantly (Figure 4f). Even greater capacity lowering will occur in aggregates of partly imperfect crystals (Figure 4g). This means that aggregation and imperfections always decrease specific capacity, even in the case of nanomaterials, but do not obligatorily cause the loss of high-rate properties. From this point of view conclusion drawn in Ref. [133] that for materials of exceptional specific power no difference exists between microsized and nanosized samples seems completely justified. In order to conclude the role of these issues an in-depth characterization of the morphology of materials should be performed including determinations of the size of crystallites and stress in them by means of the analysis of X-ray scattering patterns (the Scherrer and Rietveld methods) and the size of particles using scanning and transmittance electron microscopy (SEM and TEM). Analyses of specific surface areas S sp and porosities can also be helpful. In particular, knowing S sp, one can estimate the particle size d part by the formula based on an assumption of spherical loosely packed particles, (8) d part = 6 × 10 - + 6 / ( S sp ⋅ ρ ) where ρ is the density, or employ the so-called gapped gapless packing model so as to find the d part value and deduce the arrangement of particles in aggregates/agglomerates [142]. In some lucky circumstances, conclusions regarding a possible relationship between superior electrochemical properties and nanodimentionality are straightforward. This is the case for LiMn2O4 obtained by means of a resorcinol-formaldehyde route [85] for which specific capacity is close to the theoretical value and 74% of the initial capacity is retained at the rate of 60 C, dQ d/dI = 0.60. According to SEM micrographs, this material is represented by the particles of 50–120 nm size. The X-ray determination of the crystallite size gives 50 nm, i.e. each particle may be considered as a single crystallite. This finding supports the definition of an ideal electrode material. Ref. [24] reported electrochemical tests of LiMn2O4 obtained by means of pyrolysis of a citrate precursor in inert atmosphere. X-ray data signify that the crystallite size in it is close to 65 nm, and the particle size equals to 50–70 nm (SEM), i.e. each particle could be considered as a single crystallite. Excellent high-rate properties are found (dQ/dI = 0.60), whereas the specific capacity is lower than the theoretical value (Q =112 mAh·g–1). SEM micrographs reveal strong aggregation of particles, which probably causes a decrease in the specific capacity. Quite surprisingly, there are no other papers except the aforementioned Ref. [85] where the data on crystallite and particle sizes of the LiMn2O4 spinels are presented simultaneously. However, some results with certain reservations could be considered as evidences in favor of requirements to ideal electrode materials. For example, for perfect non-aggregated microcrystals of LiMn2O4 having the size of 300–400 nm [62] and 100 nm [86] (SEM measurements), specific capacity of 130 mAh·g–1 can be attained at low current loads. On the contrary, aggregated, imperfect nanocrystals have low specific capacity at small loads (Q = 115 mAh·g–1), whereas their high-rate properties are good (dQ/dI = 0.25) [83]. As follows from TEM data, nanosheets obtained in Ref. [99] are formed by accreted, significantly imperfect single crystals. This is enough for high specific rate (dQ/dI = 1.80), but specific capacity of this material appears too low (Q = 120 mAh·g–1). Due to the same reason similar properties are characteristic of nanorods (dQ/dI = 0.14, Q = 108 mAh·g–1) [93] possessing well defined morphologic imperfections and hollow spheres (dQ/dI = 1.46, Q = 105 mAh·g–1) [105] assembled by closely aggregated imperfect single crystals. In the case of single-crystalline nanowires (dQ/dI = 0.22, Q = 120 mAh·g–1) [108], the most developed [100] facets may be unfavorable for lithium entering and leaving because of a high potential barrier of diffusion. It should be said in all fairness that the data of Ref. [94] disagree with requirements to ideal electrode materials. In this paper, visually perfect non-aggregated microcrystals of 400–600 nm size demonstrate perfect high-rate abilities (dQ/dI = 0.19) and low specific capacity (118 mAh·g–1). In addition, a number of papers exist where the magnification of micrographs is insufficient for well-grounded judgments regarding the morphology of materials under consideration [73,76,77,98,100,110]. Among the studies of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, there are numerous papers where the morphology of materials is completely described but electrochemical properties appear insufficient. For example, there are several works where monocrystalline samples have been obtained. Single nanocrystals of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 can be prepared by the solid-state route with ball-milling [117]. 1 h thermal treatment at 400 °C gives particles whose crystallite size found by Scherrer method (26 nm) and the particle size determined from S sp measurements using Equation (8) (23 nm) and by TEM (~50 nm) appear very close. However, due to low thermal treatment temperature these single crystals are not well-faceted and imperfect, and hence the specific capacities obtained do not exceed 98 mAh·g–1. Much better single nanocrystals of 20 and 50 nm size (X-ray, SEM) have been obtained in Refs. [120,121] upon thermal treatment at 700 °C. Their specific capacities are close to the theoretical values (140 mAh·g–1) but heavy-duty properties of the materials obtained have not been studied. Single crystals of 26–60 nm (X-ray by eight different scattering lines), 50 nm (TEM) and 105 nm (S sp) are obtained by heating for 12 h at 500 °C [113]. These perfect crystals manifest excellent high-rate capabilities (dQ d/dI = 1.5) but have a reduced Q d max value (130 mAh·g–1) possibly caused by some aggregation, which begins in the course of the thermal treatment, as is seen in TEM micrographs and follows from S sp data. Rising the temperature and the sintering holding time improves electrochemical properties but increases the particle size and agglomeration/aggregation dramatically [112]. Heating for 48 h at 700 °C leads to LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 crystallites of the 0.467 μm size (X-ray). Being exposed to heating for 200 h these crystallites demonstrate a fast growth to the 3.86 μm size (X-ray), the particle size increases to 2.88 μm and agglomeration occurs, as follows from transmission electron micrographs. One should not overestimate discrepancies between X-ray and TEM data since by Scherrer formula, the X-ray line widths and crystallite sizes are inversely proportional, and calculations with extremely narrow lines are uncertain. Therefore it could be safely considered that the material in question consists of agglomerated perfect crystals. Because of their perfectness they are showing up excellent high-rate capabilities (dQ d/dI = 2.0) with Q d max = 135 mAh·g–1 reduced due to agglomeration. Interestingly, using the same raw materials and performing the thermal treatment for 48 h at 700 °C, other authors [111] obtained a well crystallized product with a particle size in the range of 3–5 μm (SEM) with no visible trend to aggregation/agglomeration, excellent high-rate properties (dQ d/dI = 0.61–2.4), and almost theoretical Q d max (147 mAh·g–1). Unfortunately, no X-ray data is given in Ref. [111] to support this conjecture and the size of crystallites remains unknown. One may consider this LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 sample to be the most close to ideality requirements. For several materials demonstrating good high-rate properties and unable to gain the theoretical capacity, clear evidences of aggregation exist. For example, complete structural data are presented for a sample synthesized from ball-milled raw materials [122]. Crystallite sizes are found as 26–68 nm (X-ray), and particle sizes are less than 40 nm (SEM), i.e. each particle can be considered as a single crystal, whereas particles are closely aggregated. Probably, just due to this latter circumstance the sample under consideration demonstrates low capacity together with fair ability to discharge by great currents (dQ/dI = 2.71). Ref. [23] presented testing data for a LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 sample obtained by means of pyrolysis of a citrate precursor. It consists of visually perfectly shaped, strongly accreted crystals of octahedral and cubo-octahedral habitus having the size of >200 nm (SEM) or 190–360 nm (S sp) and crystallites of 15–20 nm size (X-ray). Electrochemical studies show that being able to endure high current loads (dQ/dI = 2.03) this material does not achieve the theoretical capacity (Q = 105 mAh·g–1). These two examples evidence the distinct influence of aggregation on capacity. Among incompletely characterized samples, ability to fast discharge (dQ/dI = 1.16) and lowered specific capacity (Q = 128 mAh·g–1) demonstrate big, strongly aggregated, imperfect LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 crystals [123]. One more example revealing great power (dQ/dI = 0.76) and small specific capacity (Q = 130 mAg–1) is a sample consisting of nanosized crystals (d = 50 nm) [140]. It is investigated only by SEM but micrographs clearly show strong aggregation. Finally, for LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 sample possessing the best high-rate properties (dQ/dI = 0.45) and low specific capacity (Q = 127 mAh·g–1) [134], TEM micrographs evidence that its microcrystals of ~1 μm contain separated domains with clearly distinguishable boundaries. For LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, like for LiMn2O4, several studies exist where the magnification of electron micrographs is insufficient for well-based conclusions regarding the morphology of materials [17,114, 115, 124, 125]. The facts summarized in this chapter, in our opinion, undoubtedly signify that the balance between high rate properties and capacities is determined not only by the size of crystals but also by their perfectness and ability to aggregation. This is proven by the data on in-depth characterized materials demonstrating electrochemical parameters close to ideal (almost theoretical capacity and high specific power for LiMn2O4 [85] and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 [111]). For materials with non-ideal electrochemical parameters, the causes of non-ideality become understood in the light of complete and even incomplete structural information. 7 Conclusions In order to successively compete with supercapacitors, an ability of fast discharge is a must for lithium batteries. Accounting for this fact it is worth reminding that just in 2008, commercially available lithium-ion batteries of the LiNiO2||Li(C) electrode system produced by SAFT for large space and defense applications were designed for the current loads of ca. 100 C [9]. One may consider that from this moment, assignment of samples, which are able to endure the loads of at least 40 C, loses its sense, and such samples become of marginal interest for future heavy-duty usage. From this point of view, stoichiometric and substituted lithium manganese spinels are still far from existing expectations. The number of materials tested at more or less high rates hardly exceeds 20% of the papers selected for this review, and superior heavy-duty properties are found for 14 LiMn2O4 spinels and for 8 LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinels. Potentialities possibly offered by nanosized electrode materials are not fully utilized yet. Numerous microsized materials [23,60,94,110,111,113,123,125,134] demonstrate excellent electrochemical performance. It is even stated that no difference exists between microsized and nanosized samples [133]. It is therefore tempting to make at least a rough estimate of the time required for the lithium ions to fill nanosized and microsized spinel materials upon intercalation. Based on the Frenkel kinetic theory [143,144], the diffusion coefficient is expressed as (9) D = δ 2 / 2 θ where δ is the elementary step of diffusion, which is equal to the distance between equivalent positions accessible to the lithium ions, and θ is the lifetime of the lithium ion in this position. The mean speed of the lithium ion movement in the crystal is (10) w = δ / θ Using these formulas, knowing δ = 5.8 Å for spinels, taking the minimal values of D≈0.7×10–12cm2·s–1 [145] and assuming the size of a crystal as 100 nm one gets the time required for the lithium ions to pass a half of this distance as 0.21 s. This corresponds to the current rate of ~4000 C and means that nanodimension itself cannot be a prerequisite of high-rate properties of electrode materials. Therefore to complement the requirements of nanodimensionality formulated by Aricò et al. [4], it is suggested here that an ideal electrode material should consist of nonaggregated, nanosized, perfect single crystals. A balance between high rate properties and capacities should be determined not only by the size of crystals but also by their perfectness and ability to aggregation. On the one hand, this means that much work has to be done so as to obtain electrode materials consisting of non-aggregated particles of perfect morphology. On the other hand, an indispensable condition for successful outcomes of this work is the presence of the most detailed characterization data including careful determinations of both crystallite and particle sizes, perfectness and aggregation. In most studies analyzed in this review, such condition is not fulfilled. This omission must be overcome in future works. Furthermore, there is another requirement to electrode materials which, to the best of our knowledge, has never been properly articulated in the literature. This is the permeability of the system of particles forming the electrode and ensuring the accessibility of the electrode material to the electrolyte. It is equally related both to accreted crystals with pore radii decreasing upon sintering and to powders formed by densely and even loosely packed particles [142]. This requirement can be viewed from two sides. On the one hand, a minimal pore diameter should exist for each type of a solvent so as to accommodate solvated cations and anions and cause an acceptable hydrodynamic resistance to the flow of charge carriers, especially in view of the fact that confining liquids in pores significantly changes their properties and causes the predominance of repulsion over attraction [146–150]. A quick estimate of the diameter of a solvated ion can be based on the density of solvents. For the most popular commercial solvents, like ethylene carbonate and dimethyl carbonate, the densities taken from Ref. [151] give cross-sections as ca. 0.5 nm. This means that the diameters of solvated lithium cations and anions are at least 1.1 and 1.5 nm, respectively. The diameters of particles d part and pores d pore in the gapless packing of spheres are connected as [142] (11) d pore = 0.155 d part giving the minimal diameter of particles, which does not hinder the ionic transport as d part≈10 nm. In order to avoid confining effects the diameter of pores should be at least three to five times greater. On the other hand, there are some indications of increasing conductivity of electrolytes thickened with oxides when the size of oxide particles decreases. This phenomenon has been first noticed in Refs. [152,153] for glasses and is now actively pursued, especially, for polymeric and ionic liquid-containing electrolytes [154,155] but in the case of ordinary non-aqueous electrolytes and dispersions of electrode materials, there are not enough data on the dependence of their conductivity on the particle size of a dispersed additive. In order to outline the most prospective synthetic approaches enabling one to obtain true high-rate materials, let us analyze Figure 5 where capacity retentions are presented for the samples of LiMn2O4 and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinels tested at the current loads of >20 C and showing dQ d/dI<2.0. These data clearly show that ordinary solid-state methods cannot be competitive due to low capacities and poor high-rate properties of materials obtained. Probably, the only way to make them prospective for the synthesis of high-rate spinels is combining solid-state approaches with ball-milling and microwave treatment. Among nanostructured materials, LiMn2O4 nanowires can deliver three quarters of their initial capacity being loaded with the extremely high currents of 135 C. Samples obtained in hydrothermal procedures can be loaded with the currents of 90 C. Sol-gel syntheses and their varieties, like citric acid aided routes and resorcinol-formaldehyde polymerization lead to materials enduring the current loads of 60 C. The same is true for LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 obtained by means of the poly (vynil pyrrolidone) route (15 C), spray pyrolysis (20 C), and resorcinol-formaldehyde polymerization (40 C). However, hydrothermal treatment and spray drying, as mentioned above, can hardly be utilized on industrial scale. Furthermore, approaches adopted in nanochemistry are still laboratory-oriented, and their expanding seems problematic. On the other hand, potentialities of oxy- and amino-acid aided routes are exploited insufficiently. In the case of lithium-manganese spinels, these routes allow for obtaining materials of high initial capacities and, in some cases, suitable for heavy-duty applications. In view of existing medium-scale implementation of oxy- and amino-acid aided routes [156] one can suppose that further achievements in obtaining spinel materials for high-rate electrochemical applications may lie just in this field. However, our knowledge of these routes, as discussed in Ref. [20], still remains incomplete. For example, from the point of view of the specific surface area and catalytic activity of the powders obtained, glyoxylic, oxalacetic and ketoglutaric acids are preferred to 17 others including citric acid [156], but these have never been employed in syntheses of electrode materials. The poly (ethylene glycol) assisted tartaric-acid-aided route leads to LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 micro- or nanocrystals of low aggregation and equally good heavy-duty properties, regardless of their size [133]. On the contrary, in syntheses of other oxide materials by means of citric-acid-aided routes, adding ethylene glycol changes the morphology of oxides to nanosheets, nanorods, and nanoflowers [157, 158]. This means that significant efforts should be undertaken so as to select an ‘optimal’ oxyacid and to understand the role of polyols in synthetic procedures. We do hope that future efforts of materials scientists in the field of electrode materials would be directed along these lines and would contribute to keeping lithium batteries afloat in the struggle for a worthy place among electrochemical energy systems of the 21st century. Potapenko is a junior scientist at Joint Department of Electrochemical Energy Systems, Kyiv, Ukraine. Her research interests lie in the field of synthesis, characterization and testing of electrode materials. She is completing her PhD thesis on lithium manganese spinels for high-rate electrochemical applications. Sviatoslav A. Kirillov is acting director of Joint Department of Electrochemical Energy Systems, Kyiv, Ukraine, the only academic institution in the field in ex-Soviet countries, whose scientists powered scientific equipment for, e.g., the Venus launch module and Kola Superdeep Borehole. Dr Kirillov received his PhD in Inorganic Chemistry from Institute of General and Inorganic Chemistry, Kyiv, and obtained DSc degree (habilitation) from Moscow State University. In 1992–2000, he was a holder of several visiting professorships in Greece (Patras University, Institute of Chemical Engineering and High-Temperature Chemical Processes, Patras, University of Thessaly). His research interests embrace interactions and dynamics in disordered systems, synthesis, characterization and testing of materials for electrochemistry, adsorption and catalysis. He is the author or co-author of about 170 papers, over 10 books and chapters in books, and 6 patents.

coredata.dc:description: In order to successively compete with supercapacitors, an ability of fast discharge is a must for lithium-ion batteries. From this point of view, stoichiometric and substituted lithium manganese spinels as cathode materials are one of the most prospective candidates, especially in their nanosized form. In this article, an overview of the most recent data regarding physico-chemical and electrochemical properties of lithium manganese spinels, especially, LiMn2O4 and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, synthesized by means of various methods is presented, with special emphasis of their use in high-rate electrochemical applications. In particular, specific capacities and rate capabilities of spinel materials are analyzed. It is suggested that reduced specific capacity is determined primarily by the aggregation of material particles, whereas good high-rate capability is governed not only by the size of crystallites but also by the perfectness of crystals. The most technologically advantageous solutions are described, existing gaps in the knowledge of spinel materials are outlined, and the ways of their filling are suggested, in a hope to be helpful in keeping lithium batteries afloat in the struggle for a worthy place among electrochemical energy systems of the 21st century.
